title: 112_s3084
content: The "VISN Reorganization Act of 2012" is the short title of this Act. It deals with the administration of Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The "VISN Reorganization Act of 2012" amends Subchapter I of chapter 73 of title 38, United States Code, by adding a new section on Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The Secretary is required to organize the Veterans Health Administration into 12 geographically defined networks aligned with the Department's mission and national goals. The Secretary ensures that each Veterans Integrated Service Network implements national goals and maintains a regional integrated healthcare system by forming alliances with other healthcare organizations and managing a regional budget. The Secretary oversees the regional budget for Veterans Health Administration activities in the Network, ensuring alignment with department guidelines and balanced budgets. They use national metrics to improve healthcare delivery and ensure high-quality clinical programs and services in medical centers and clinics within the Network. The Secretary ensures high-quality clinical programs and services are provided in medical centers and clinics within the Network, reducing duplication of functions and promoting collaboration for effective patient care, safety, education, and research. The Secretary ensures collaboration and cooperation within each Veteran Integrated Service Network to maximize patient care, safety, education, and research, including assessing consolidation of functions with other entities like Veterans Benefits Administration and Department of Defense. The locations covered under the Secretary's oversight include offices of the Veterans Benefits Administration, National Cemetery Administration, Department of Defense, Coast Guard, State and local agencies assisting veterans, medical schools, government offices, and emergency services at federal, State, and local levels. The Secretary oversees various locations including medical schools, government offices, emergency services, and other organizations. The Veterans Integrated Service Networks are required to develop and share innovations, with each network having one headquarters office. The Secretary ensures each Veterans Integrated Service Network has one headquarters co-located with a VA medical center. The Secretary may employ up to 65 employees at each headquarters and must report annually to Congress on employment. The Committee on Veterans' Affairs of the House of Representatives submits a report on employment at the headquarters of Veterans Integrated Service Networks, including the number of individuals employed, their titles, and positions within the Veterans Health Administration. The Secretary shall conduct a triennial review and assessment of the structure and operations of Veterans Integrated Service Networks, including employment positions at headquarters and impact on the Department's budget. The Secretary shall conduct a review of the Veterans Integrated Service Networks every three years and submit a report with recommendations to improve them to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the relevant title. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is required to consolidate the 21 Veterans Integrated Service Networks into 12 geographically defined networks within one year of the enactment of the Act. This includes combining specific networks into single entities. Integrated Service Networks 2, 3, 4, 5, 9, 10, 11, 12, 15, and 23 will be consolidated into fewer Veterans Integrated Service Networks. Veterans Integrated Service Networks 12, 15, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, and 22 will be combined into fewer networks. The consolidation of Veterans Integrated Service Networks 20, 21, and 22 into fewer networks will involve combining their headquarters into a single location. The Act aims to consolidate Veterans Integrated Service Networks 20, 21, and 22 headquarters into a single location and provide reemployment assistance for individuals affected by the elimination of positions. The Secretary must submit an implementation plan within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Act consolidates Veterans Integrated Service Networks headquarters and offers reemployment assistance. The Secretary must submit an implementation plan within 180 days. Headquarters offices not co-located with a VA medical center may be relocated. The Secretary may relocate headquarters not co-located with a VA medical center upon lease expiration or renew the lease. A report must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs before renewing or engaging in a new lease. Before renewing or engaging in a new lease under paragraph (1)(B), the Secretary must submit a report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs detailing the reasons for such actions. The report should include a list of VA medical centers with underutilized buildings, the cost of the current lease, and other relevant financial information. The Secretary must submit a report detailing underutilized square footage, current lease costs, and new lease costs for VA medical centers before renewing or engaging in a new lease. SEC. 3. Regional support centers for veterans integrated service networks. Sec. 7309A establishes regional support centers within the Veterans Health Administration to evaluate the effectiveness and efficiency of Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The centers assess finance operations and compliance activities to ensure quality work. The Veterans Health Administration established regional support centers to evaluate the quality of work in finance operations and compliance activities within Veterans Integrated Service Networks. These assessments include outreach to veterans of specific operations, programs for women veterans, addressing homelessness among veterans, and energy consumption efficiency. The Veterans Integrated Service Network conducts programs addressing homelessness among veterans and assesses energy consumption efficiency. Regional support centers are established to carry out these functions and are located with Department of Veterans Affairs medical centers. The location of regional support centers established under subsection (a) will be determined by the Secretary and co-located with a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center. The Secretary may choose a different location but must provide a report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs explaining the reasons for not co-locating with a medical center. The report on underutilized buildings in the Veterans Integrated Service Network includes a list of medical centers, total square footage, and lease costs for regional support centers. Initial staffing for these centers will be provided by the Secretary. The Secretary will transfer employees from headquarters to regional support centers for initial staffing. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the title. SEC. 4. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not require any changes in the location or type of medical care provided by Department of Veterans Affairs facilities.
